Key Arguments: The legislation infringes on the right to freedom of opinion and expression as outlined in the UN Universal Declaration of Human Rights.
The bill could lead to censorship and suppression of opinions that are critical of those in power.
There is concern over who at ACMA decides what constitutes misinformation and disinformation, citing past examples where information initially labeled as misinformation was later accepted.
The potential for abuse of power by ACMA outweighs any benefits of the legislation.
Individuals should have the autonomy to discern truth without government interference.
Main Themes: Mistrust in government's ability to fairly regulate misinformation
Historical examples of changing narratives around misinformation
Notable Quotes: Australians will not have the right to freedom of online opinion and expression as expressed by the UN Universal Declaration of Human Rights if this Orwellian Bill becomes law.
If freedom of opinion means anything at all, it means the right to tell people online what they do not want to hear.
Donâ€™t give ACMA (or anyone) these new powers. Their risk of application abuse outweighs any potential benefit to combat so called misinformation and disinformation.
